text:
I'm gonna wow my guests with a Christmas twist 
on a classic beef bourguignon, a beautiful tender

rich herby beef stew, perfect for this time 
of year. We're taking this beef bourguignon

to new heights. We need to start by marinating 
these, so I'm going to chop it into like five

centimetre chunks. This is one and a half kilos 
of beef cheeks. We're going to go in with a bottle

of beautiful French Burgundy. The acidity in that 
wine very gently starts to flavour the beef. Four

or five lovely bay leaves goes in, I've got some 
rosemary in there a little bit of thyme as well.

Four or five cloves of garlic. Four sticks 
of celery. Then I'm gonna get some carrots.

We've got one onion, roughly chopped. I'm 
gonna season very generously with black pepper.

Then I want just a little pinch of ground cloves, 
the taste of Christmas. A couple of teaspoons of

dijon mustard. It's not classic but it's 
Christmas guys. I'm gonna mix it up with my hands,

gently gently, don't get in my shirt. 
Cover that in some greaseproof paper,

then tomorrow I'm gonna make the 
most amazing stew out of that.

That red wine has already penetrated the 
meat, look how it's changed the colour.

So into a colander, then with the meat what 
I want to do is get that into some flour,

so just regular plain flour onto a nice little 
tray or platter like this. I'm going to add

just a little knob of butter and a little bit 
of olive oil, and the combination together

means you can go to a slightly higher temperature 
but still get that gorgeous flavour and golden

crispy outside. So as this is frying beautifully 
and getting golden, we're going to slowly fry off

all of these veggies. One of the things that 
I love to do to make it even more Christmassy,

that's not classic for sure, is chestnuts. 
Look at these, they have that amazing sort

of sweetness and nuttiness, and just crumbling 
them in your hand will just add to that gravy.

At this point in time add the red wine, this goes 
into the stockpot and just top this up with some

boiling water or some stock. Just enough to cover 
the beef. And that will now slow cook for about

four hours at 150 degrees Celsius. So I'm going 
to get this in the oven and get this cooking.

We're at that point now where the whole thing's 
coming together. Just have a little look,

how shiny that is. Let's just see how tender 
it is - look at that falling apart, that is

the thing about the cheek. Oh yeah! So look at 
that beautiful, chunky, shiny beef bourguignon.

My dad is gonna absolutely love that. Guys we got 
a little bit of beef bourguignon here. Everyone

help yourself. That's so nice! Dad's gone back 
for seconds, if you want seconds everyone tuck in!
